unnormalised: So, someone asked about payment options on Indian e-commerce sites, right? Well, there's a whole bunch. Most places take credit cards (Visa, Mastercard, Amex – the usual suspects). You'll often see RuPay accepted too; it's the Indian card scheme, and good to support local! And don't forget about debit cards; pretty much every bank's card works nowadays.
normalised: So, someone asked about payment options on Indian e-commerce sites, right? Well, there is a whole bunch. Most places take credit cards (V-I-S-A, Mastercard, Amex – the usual suspects). You will often see RuPay accepted too; it is the Indian card scheme, and good to support local! And don't forget about debit cards; pretty much every bank's card works nowadays.

unnormalised: UPI (Unified Payments Interface) is HUGE here. Bhim, Google Pay, PhonePe, Paytm – they all use UPI. Super convenient; just scan a QR code or enter a UPI ID, and you're done. Works for small amounts like Rs. 10 for chai to big purchases like a new ₹50,000 fridge. Wallets are still around, but not as popular as UPI. You might find cashback offers if you use them, though!
normalised: U-P-I (Unified Payments Interface) is H-U-G-E here. Bhim, Google Pay, PhonePe, Paytm – they all use U-P-I. Super convenient; just scan a Q-R code or enter a U-P-I I-D, and you are done. Works for small amounts like rupee ten for chai to big purchases like a new rupee fifty thousand fridge. Wallets are still around, but not as popular as U-P-I. You might find cashback offers if you use them, though!

unnormalised: Netbanking is also an option, even though it feels a bit old-school. You get redirected to your bank's website, log in, and approve the transaction. Can be a bit clunky, but safe and reliable, especially for amounts over Rs. 2000. Some smaller sites might only offer netbanking.
normalised: Netbanking is also an option, even though it feels a bit old-school. You get redirected to your bank's website, log in, and approve the transaction. Can be a bit clunky, but safe and reliable, especially for amounts over rupee two thousand. Some smaller sites might only offer netbanking.

unnormalised: Finally, cash on delivery (COD) is still a thing, even though everyone's trying to move away from it. If you're not comfortable paying online, you can pay the delivery guy when he brings your order. But be aware that some sellers might charge extra for COD, like Rs. 50 or so. Check the site carefully before you order!
